Award.AwardTitle: Sustaining and Evaluating STEM Teacher Quality and Retention at Cal Teach Berkeley

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Through funding from the Robert Noyce Scholarship Program, this Track 1 Phase 2 project will address the established and growing national need to increase the quality, quantity, and diversity of the K-12 teaching workforce in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). The University of California-Berkeley (UC Berkeley) program will: (1) build on its current and expanding Cal Teach program which supports undergraduate students as they pursue their STEM disciplinary degrees along with credentials in teaching mathematics and science, particularly in urban schools; (2) leverage a new collaboration with the University of California-Merced (UC Merced) to offer education courses and activities for STEM undergraduates at both campuses and a secondary teaching credential in mathematics or science at UC Berkeley; and (3) enhance the overall efforts and activities through strong extant partnerships with local school districts (Berkeley, Oakland Unified, and Merced City) and with local research and outreach institutions (e.g., Lawrence Hall of Science and the Chabot Space and Science Center). The project will support a total of more than one-hundred (100) students by providing (a) internships to twelve (12) lower division undergraduate students per year to engage these students in research, professional development, and interactions with outreach partners, and (b) scholarships to nine (9) upper division students per year who are participants in the Cal Teach program. These scholarship awards will be highly visible within the STEM disciplines at UC Berkeley and UC Merced, and will be identified as awards which reflect student accomplishment and success.

This Noyce Phase 2 project will be an integrated program, with early and frequent field placements, allowing aspiring teachers to develop both deep subject matter understanding and exemplary pedagogical skills as they engage in both theory and practice. To accomplish this, the project will engage faculty from the STEM content areas as well as from the Graduate School of Education at UC Berkeley through an interdisciplinary approach to teacher preparation that has been shown to be critical in the context of training mathematics and science teachers for urban schools. In the process of project implementation, the project team will investigate the following questions: (i) What are the key activities which generate successful recruiting and retention of STEM major candidates with diverse backgrounds--including gender, race, ethnicity, and socioeconomic status--compared to entering teacher candidates for the state and national teacher workforce? (ii) How do teacher candidates, their university supervisors, and, once they begin a teaching position, their administrators, perceive the quality of their preparation for a teaching career in urban schools? What gaps and other issues need to be addressed in their preparation? (iii) What is the nature of classroom practices for these teachers? What is the impact on their K-12 students' learning? and (iv) What is the long term retention rate of these teachers? To what extent do these teachers assume a leadership role in their schools/districts? Research related to the key factors behind answers to above questions will lead to a national model for success in STEM teaching in urban settings that will also stimulate broadening participation in STEM and promoting social justice through mathematics and science teaching and learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CalTeach Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship project has been a key component of the CalTeach program at University of California (UC), Berkeley. CalTeach aims to prepare for science, engineering and mathematics (STEM) undergraduates for K-12 teaching as a career; students simultaneously earn a disciplinary degree, enroll in education coursework leading to a California teaching credential, and engage in a variety of teaching opportunities with K-12 students. During this Noyce project, we offered 47 substantial scholarships for advanced undergraduate students who committed to completing their secondary math and science teaching credential and working in high-needs schools, including to both UC Berkeley and UC Merced STEM majors. We also recruited a greater number of highly-qualified STEM undergraduate majors into teaching careers through 31 summer internships for students in science museums and non-profit science education settings, and provided 29 externs with intensive classroom placements.

 

During 2015-2020, we strengthened partnerships with 6 STEM education partners we began working with during a previous Noyce award--Lawrence Hall of Science, Exploratorium, California Academy of Sciences, Oakland Zoo, and Chabot Space & Science Center--and initiated 4 new partnerships with the Bay Area Discovery Museum, Kids Discovery Station, Berkeley Unboxing Data Science, and Mission Science Workshop. We also strengthened partnerships with several local urban and rural high-needs school districts, including Berkeley, Oakland, San Francisco, and West Contra Costa Unified School Districts. Importantly, through a collaboration with UC Merced, an Hispanic-serving institution, we broadened our service of California urban high needs schools to those in the rural Central Valley. CalTeach recruited a high proportion of underrepresented participants into our program and supported them to get their math and science teaching credential. Strong ties between CalTeach faculty from the STEM content areas at Berkeley and Merced, and education faculty at the Berkeley Graduate School of Education (GSE), provided additional opportunities for collaboration in teacher education.

 

The Noyce project also provided an opportunity to engage in program evaluation of Noyce program impact, and a research study focusing on classroom practices of graduates from UC Berkeley teacher education programs, thereby contributing to knowledge in the STEM teacher education field.  Preparation of beginning teachers for complex teaching practices has received considerable attention in the last decade, but few studies have followed graduates into the classroom to examine how particular orientations to teaching are enacted. Over the course of this award, we conducted a mixed-methods study of teachers who completed the undergraduate CalTeach program and a graduate teacher education program at UC Berkeley. We began with a broad research question, What is the character of Berkeley graduates’ science and mathematics teaching practices? And continued more specifically, to what extent do inquiry-based science and practices show up in their classrooms? 

 

Berkeley teachers’ classroom observations and parallel interview responses indicated that they placed high value on instructional activities that involved students discussing their thinking and learning collaboratively, asking open-ended questions to provoke critical  thinking, were student-centered, and provided room to reason both concretely and abstractly. Graduates were more easily able to describe and plan for such activities than they were able to implement them consistently. Additionally interview data revealed that graduates’ valuing of classroom culture/community, as well as their expressed desires to give students more authority in the classroom, both emerged as themes that influenced the activities that graduates discussed enacting or wanting to enact. Classroom culture and management was also recognized as a necessary component of a classroom in which students were given greater autonomy or freedom in the STEM learning process. A number of conference presentations to STEM teacher educators at national conferences, as well as a 2019 peer-reviewed conference publication and a manuscript currently in preparation for a STEM teacher education journal, have resulted from our Noyce project activities.
